title: Chaos breaks out at a drug-fuelled dance music event as several youngsters overdose
text:
Three people were taken to hospital in a critical condition after taking drugs at a dance music event on Friday night.

Chaos broke out at Listen In, at Mount Smart Stadium, in Auckland, New Zealand, with two revellers climbing a 25-metre high marquee at the drug-fuelled concert.

More than 20,000 people attended the event, described as 'insane' by some attendees.

One witness reported seeing a person being wheeled out on a stretcher unconscious and said drug taking was rife.

'It was actually quite insane,' they told the NZ Herald. 'Towards the end of the night you could really see the impact of whatever they had taken.

'I remember looking down and there was literally a girl being wheeled out of the concert unconscious. Her head was back, her mouth was open, body was limp.'

They added at the end of night they could see little bags used for containing drugs littered across the event site.

Four people were taken to hospital in total after reportedly overdosing.

The three people who were in a critical condition are now stable, an ambulance spokesman said.

The witness also said they saw fights breaking out and security guards were pulling girls over railings to get them out of danger.

Three people were taken to hospital in a critical condition after overdosing on drugs

Chaos broke out at Listen In, at Mount Smart Stadium, in Auckland, New Zealand, with some revellers climbing a 25-metre high marquee at the drug-fuelled concert (pictured)

Other social media videos taken inside the marquee showed revellers climbing the metal rigging holding the tent in place.

Other social media videos taken inside the marquee showed revellers climbing the metal rigging holding the marquee in place

One person appeared to lose his jacket as he climbed the steel girder.

The director of Auckland Stadiums James Parkinson said they had safe disposal units and drugs were confiscated from people at the gates.

He also denied drug taking was rife at the concert, and said the vast majority of visitors had a great time.

'Unfortunately, these incidents do highlight the inherent risks of drug-taking,' he said.

He added there had been discussions about allowing pill testers to test the drugs being brought into the event.

But he said returning illegal substances to revellers - which effectively means condoning their use - puts the venue in a difficult legal position.

Daily Mail Australia has contacted Auckland Stadiums for comment.
